awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Solar Physics Program at Montana State University
awd_abstract_narration:
Montana State University (MSU) will offer a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Program in solar and space physics. Students will conduct cutting-edge research in solar and space physics, to investigate how magnetic fields evolve on the Sun and release a large amount of energy into heliosphere, which may impact the space weather. Student research frequently results in joint professional publications and conference presentations with their MSU mentors. Students will also take introductory courses in solar physics, and tutorials in computer programming, ethics in research, and preparation and application for graduate schools. These experiences will help students develop independence, creativity, and interest in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) fields, strengthen practical research skills and communication skills, and make educated decisions on whether to attend the graduate school and to pursue research as a profession. The program provides an important service to the solar astrophysics discipline. With its strong space science component, the program also offers benefits to society by providing citizens and future researchers with an understanding of space weather impacts on Earth's space environment. The program is dedicated to education and training of a diverse work force in STEM fields.

The main objectives of this REU program are: 1) provide a high-quality state-of-the-art research experience, 2) develop independence, creativity, and interest in physics and astronomy graduate school, 3) demonstrate how academic knowledge acquired in classes relates to real-world research problems, 4) develop and strengthen practical research skills and 5) encourage participation by women and underrepresented minorities in scientific research.  Students will carry out individual research projects for ten weeks during the summer, under the supervision of the faculty and research staff and in collaboration with the graduate students at MSU. The research projects will involve the analysis of the state-of-the-art observations from space missions and ground-based observatories, magneto-hydrodynamic modeling, as well as space hardware instrumentation. The target group of the program includes undergraduates majoring in Physics, Astronomy, Mathematics, Engineering, and Computer Sciences. The program strongly encourages participation by underrepresented groups in STEM fields and students with little access to research opportunities. This project is jointly funded by the AGS REU program (Educational Linkages), the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Solar Terrestrial program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates program in Solar Astrophysics and Space Physics at Montana State University has been supported by the National Science Foundation since 2003. In 2020, the program was canceled due to the pandemic. In 2021, the program was re-started and recovering from the pandemic. Over the past three summers, the program has recruited twenty-two REU studens. A significant number of them are female and minority students, reflecting the program's effort to grow a diverse and inclusive research program in Montana state.

REU students have participated in cutting-edge research in solar astrophysics and space science. They analyze state-of-the-art observations from a large array of space telescopes. They model and measure the evolution of the magnetic field and radiation output of the Sun over a solar cycle. They explore mechanisms that store a vast amount of energy over days, and then suddenly release it, ejecting a large number of energetic particles into heliosphere. They also build and calibrate instruments that are sent to space to observe the Sun, the magnetosphere, the ionosphere, and the atmosphere. The REU research addresses fundamental problems in space and astrophysics such as the physical process of magnetic reconnection and particle energization. Answers to these questions improve our understanding of the inner workings of many active stars, and enhance our capabilities to forefast space weather.

The REU program helps students develop research and communication skills. They frequently present and discuss their research with the research group in the department, and with the larger research communities at professional conferences. Over the past three years, REU students have given twenty-three presentations at professional conferences such as the American Geophysical Union meeting, the American Astronomical Society meeting, and the Triennial Earth-Sun Summit meeting. They also visit local libraries to talk to K-12 students about the Sun and solar eclipse! Through these activities, they have disseminated their findings to research communities as well as the general public.

Many REU students are attending the gradual school to continue their study and research in STEM areas. The REU program has recruited research mentors from graduate students and early career researchers and faculty. They have obtained invaluable professional development experience through guiding undergraduate research, and in the mean while, have brought in many new perspects to broaden the scope of the program and enrich the experience of undergraduate students tremendously.

 The solar astrophysics and space physics program at Montana State University has been dedicated to education and training of the next-generation solar and space physicists. The program has also contributed to NSF's broader goal to cultivate interest and strengthen skills in STEM areas among a diverse population of undergraduate students. The complete information of the program, including the program objectives, research projects, participant information, student activities, and lists of student publications and presentations, can be viewed at http://solar.physics.montana.edu/REU/
